triples.name: Evolutionary psychology
triples.relevance: The paper tests the evolutionary psychology perspective as an explanation for universal sex differences in mate preferences.

triples.name: Sexual selection in humans
triples.relevance: Sexual selection provides the biological basis for understanding sex differences in mating preferences and partner choice.

triples.name: Mate choice in humans
triples.relevance: The core research problem addressed is understanding how humans select mates across different cultures and sexes.

triples.name: Physical attractiveness
triples.relevance: Physical attractiveness is a key trait examined in sex differences, as men prefer more attractive young mates.

triples.name: Cross-cultural psychology
triples.relevance: The study employs cross-cultural methodology across 45 countries to test the universality of mate preference patterns.

triples.name: Gender equality
triples.relevance: Gender equality is tested as a key predictor of sex differences in mate preferences across cultures.

triples.name: Sex differences in psychology
triples.relevance: The paper examines sex differences in psychological preferences and mate selection behaviors.

triples.name: Disease ecology
triples.relevance: Pathogen prevalence from disease ecology is tested as a potential predictor of variation in mate preferences across countries.

triples.name: Replication crisis
triples.relevance: The paper directly addresses the replication crisis by conducting a large-scale replication of classic mate preference studies with new data.
